questions.question: During ward rounds, you encounter a patient who has been admitted with esophageal carcinoma. What is the most likely presentation for this patient?

options.A: Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids
options.B: Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids Explanation: Esophageal carcinoma typically presents with dysphagia, initially to solids and later to liquids , as the tumour obstructs and narrows the esophagus. Carcinoma Esophagus Types Squamous Cell Carcinoma Adenocarcinoma Risk Factors Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Smoking, Alcohol, Hot beverages, N-nitroso foods, Adenocarcinoma: Obesity, Gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett's esophagus Clinical Features Progressive dysphagia (initially for solids followed by liquids), Anorexia, Weight loss , Odynophagia, and Regurgitation. Advanced symptoms: Hoarseness, Aspiration, Choking, etc. Investigation Endoscopy: Tumor visualisation, Biopsies, Chromoendoscopy, NBI Barium contrast study: Tumor as ulcerated/stenotic lesion Bronchoscopy: Check airway spread Endoscopic & Percutaneous Ultrasonography: EUS for staging tumour (T stage) and para esophageal nodes Percutaneous ultrasound of cervical nodes with FNA CT scan: Distant node assessment FDG-PET scan: Detects nodes/metastases, not for tumour staging Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids (Option A) is more typical of conditions like achalasia cardia , which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing. Chest pain (Option C) can occur in esophageal carcinoma; it is less common as an initial presentation compared to dysphagia . Chest pain in esophageal cancer usually occurs in advanced stages or if there is tumour invasion into nearby structures . Neck mass (Option D) can occur if the cancer metastasises to the lymph nodes in the neck (e.g., Virchow's node ), but this is not the most common initial presentation. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1135, 1136, 1137, 1138, 1139.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient with peptic ulcer disease presents with persistent abdominal pain despite treatment at multiple hospitals. He has ulcers in the jejunum and ileum. His gastric pH is <2, and after discontinuing PPIs, his gastrin levels are 10 times higher than normal. What is the likely lesion, and what are the boundaries of the triangle containing it? B. III Insulinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas pancreas

options.C: Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
options.D: Gastrinoma; triangle formed by only common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of

questions.explanation: of pancreas Correct Answer: C) Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas Explanation: This patient’s clinical presentation of persistent peptic ulcers , especially in the jejunal and ileal regions , combined with elevated gastrin levels (even after stopping PPIs) and a gastric pH <2 , is highly suggestive of a gastrinoma . Gastrinomas are tumours that secrete excess gastrin, commonly leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome , which causes multiple peptic ulcers due to high gastric acid production. The gastrinoma triangle refers to a specific anatomical region in the pancreas where gastrinomas are most commonly located. (Pissaros triangle) this triangle is bordered by: Junction between cystic duct and CBD (option D ruled out) Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum (D2-D3 junction) Junction between the head and neck of the pancreas Insulinoma; triangle formed (Option A) : Insulinomas are pancreatic tumours that secrete insulin , not gastrin . They cause hypoglycemia rather than peptic ulcers, so this option doesn’t fit with the patient’s symptoms or diagnostic findings. (Option B ruled out) Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 703

questions.question: An intern assists in laparoscopic surgery, and the resident explains the instruments and operating ports. The surgeon then asks, "What is the angle between the camera port and the working port called?" B. III Elevation angle
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Azimuth's angle Explanation: Azimuth's angle is the correct term for describing the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery. The ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° for maximum productivity. Angles of laparoscopy Azimuth angle It is the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery; the ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° to avoid clashing of the instruments. Manipulation angle It is the angle between two working ports, and the ideal angle for this is 60°. Elevation angle This term is more related to the vertical positioning of instruments or the camera in relation to the surgical field, not the angle between ports; the ideal angle for this is also 60°. Crossing angle (Option C) is not a term specifically used to describe the angle between the camera port and the working port. Reference: NIH Link Article Link

questions.question: What is the Truelove and Witts classification used for? A. III Acute severe ulcerative colitis
questions.explanation: III Acute severe ulcerative colitis Correct Answer: A) III Acute severe ulcerative colitis Explanation: The Truelove and Witts classification is specifically used to assess the severity of ulcerative colitis (UC). Truelove and Witts classification for Ulcerative Colitis Severity Stool Frequency Systemic Symptoms and signs Mild <4 stools/day No systemic signs of toxicity Moderate >4 stools/day Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP Severe >6 stools/day Fever, tachycardia, anaemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminemia, Elevated ESR, CRP Fulminant >10 stools/day Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, “Toxic megacolon” (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases ARDS (Option B) is acute respiratory distress syndrome involving the lungs, and the Truelove and Witts classification is not used for this. Acute encephalitis (Option C) is an inflammation of the brain, typically caused by infection, and the Truelove and Witts classification has no role here. Acute pancreatitis (Option D) is an inflammation of the pancreas, and it is not evaluated using the Truelove and Witts classification. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1319

questions.question: Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutation: A. Familial adenomatous polyposis i. SMAD4 B. Juvenile polyposis ii. STK11 C. Tuberous sclerosis iii. APC gene D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome iv. TSC1
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) A-iii, B-i, C-iv, D-ii Explanation: A. Familial adenomatous polyposis iii. APC gene It is an a utosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5. It is characterised by numerous intestinal polyps, which, if left untreated, have a h igh risk of developing colorectal cancer B. Juvenile polyposis i. SMAD4 It is also an autosomal dominant disorder that commonly affects children under 5 years of age, It is characterised by pedunculated polyps, usually less than 3 cm in diameter. It is linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes , part of the TGF- β signalling pathway. C. Tuberous sclerosis iv. Treatment Surgical resection (diverticulectomy or segmental resection) if symptomatic. questions.question: A patient with grade 4 hemorrhoids underwent surgery, identify the instrument.
questions.explanation: require surgical intervention. Rubber band ligation (RBL) is commonly used for hemorrhoid treatment, especially for grade 2 and 3 hemorrhoids , but may be attempted for early grade 4 cases before surgery. If the patient underwent surgery , the most likely instrument used would be a hemorrhoidectomy (stapler or excision-based) rather than a band kit . However, if ligation was performed prior to surgery , a haemorrhoid band kit could have been used. Hemorrhoid Treatment Options Grade of Hemorrhoids Treatment Options Grade 1 (No prolapse) Lifestyle modification, fiber, sitz bath, topical agents Grade 2 (Prolapse, spontaneous reduction) Rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared coagulation Grade 3 (Prolapse, manual reduction needed) Rubber band ligation, surgical excision if persistent symptoms Grade 4 (Irreducible prolapse) Surgical options: Hemorrhoidectomy (excision or stapler), laser hemorrhoidoplasty Haemorrhoid resection kit (Option A): incorrect because resection is not performed using a specific "kit"; rather, standard surgical instruments or a stapler are used . Stapler kit (Option B): incorrect because stapled hemorrhoidopexy (PPH) is an option, but not typically described as a "band kit" . CO2 laser (Option D): incorrect because laser hemorrhoidoplasty is an alternative to excision but is not the standard method for grade 4 hemorrhoids .

questions.question: A 33-year-old male presents with sudden onset acute abdominal pain , constipation for 1 day , persistent hiccups , and occasional vomiting . An abdominal X-ray was performed. Identify the pathology.
questions.explanation: abdominal pain and constipation are classic features. Persistent hiccups suggest diaphragmatic irritation due to massive bowel distension. Vomiting occurs as obstruction progresses. X-ray Findings: Massively dilated sigmoid colon with a characteristic "coffee bean" or "omega loop" sign . Few or no air-fluid levels , differentiating it from a small bowel obstruction. Absence of significant small bowel dilatation , favoring sigmoid over caecal volvulus. Management: Initial: Sigmoidoscopic detorsion. Definitive: Elective sigmoidectomy to prevent recurrence. Emergency: If gangrene or perforation is suspected, immediate surgery is required . questions.question: A 34-year-old male undergoes an open appendectomy for acute appendicitis. The choice of incision was McBurney's incision. Postoperatively, after a few days, he presents with pain and bulging in the right lower quadrant, which is diagnosed as an indirect inguinal hernia. Which nerve injury during the appendectomy is most likely responsible for this complication?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ilioinguinal nerve Explanation: Injury to the ilioinguinal nerve during an appendectomy, especially with McBurney's incision, is a documented complication that can lead to weakness of the inguinal canal structures. This weakness can predispose the patient to the development of an indirect inguinal hernia. The complications associated with appendectomy are listed below: Complication Description 1. Wound infection The MC postoperative complication involves infection at the surgical site. 2. Intraabdominal abscess Collection of pus within the abdominal cavity, typically due to infection. 3. Ileus Temporary cessation of bowel function, leading to abdominal distension and discomfort. 4. Venous thrombosis leading to embolism Formation of blood clots in the veins, which can travel to the lungs or other parts of the body. 5. Portal pyaemia (Pylephlebitis) Infection and thrombosis of the portal vein, a rare but serious complication. 6. Adhesive intestinal obstruction Formation of scar tissue causing bowel obstruction; MC late complication 7. Fecal fistula Leakage from the appendiceal stump. 8. Nerve injury Injury to the Ilioinguinal nerve and iliohypogastric nerve Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery Edition 6th Pg. 935

questions.question: What is the most likely cause of lower right abdominal pain and rebound tenderness in a patient with Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Appendicitis Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate acute appendicitis, despite the presence of Meckel's diverticulum. Lower right abdominal pain with rebound tenderness is a classic sign of acute appendicitis, and the presence of a Meckel's diverticulum does not change this presentation. While Meckel's diverticulum can cause abdominal pain, the specific location and presence of rebound tenderness strongly suggest appendicitis as the primary pathology. Perforation (Option A): While perforation of Meckel's diverticulum can occur, it typically presents with more diffuse abdominal pain and peritonitis rather than localized right lower quadrant pain. The presentation described is more consistent with appendicitis (Option A ruled out). Perforation would likely cause more widespread symptoms and signs of peritoneal irritation. Intestinal obstruction (Option B): Meckel's diverticulum can cause intestinal obstruction, but this typically presents with colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention rather than localized rebound tenderness (Option B ruled out). The absence of these obstruction symptoms makes this diagnosis less likely. Cholecystitis (Option D): Cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness, not lower right abdominal pain. The location of pain and the presence of rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant is inconsistent with cholecystitis (Option D ruled out). Murphy's sign would be expected in cholecystitis, which is elicited in the right upper quadrant. Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 1297

questions.question: A patient presents with an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option?
questions.explanation: irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision is the most appropriate treatment to address the potential complications associated with the irreducible mass. surgical intervention should focus on excising the strangulated tissue and do suture repair. Then plan for a definite repair after few days. Incorrect Options: Option B - Umbilical excision with mesh hernioplasty: This option combines the excision of the umbilicus with the reinforcement of the abdominal wall using a mesh to prevent recurrence. It is often used in larger hernias or when there is significant weakening of the abdominal wall. Mesh hernioplasty is contraindicated in stangulation Option C - Mesh hernioplasty: This involves reinforcing the abdominal wall defect with a mesh without excising the umbilicus. It is generally used for larger or recurrent hernias to prevent recurrence. Incorrect Options: Option B - Fistula in ano: A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the skin around the anus. The pain and swelling are typically localized around the anus and not in the gluteal area. Option C - Fissure in ano : An anal fissure is a small tear in the lining of the anus, often caused by trauma or strain during bowel movements. Severe pain during and after bowel movements, possibly with bleeding, but usually localized to the anal region rather than the gluteal region. Option D - Gluteal abscess: A gluteal abscess is a collection of pus in the gluteal region, often due to infection. It may be related to trauma or infection. Pain, swelling, and redness in the gluteal region. While this condition could fit the description, pilonidal sinus is more specific to the scenario described, especially in the context of prolonged sitting.

In this procedure, the fundus of the stomach is wrapped completely (360 degrees) around the lower esophagus to reinforce the lower esophageal sphincter, preventing acid reflux. Incorrect Options: Option B - Partial gastrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of a portion of the stomach. It is not typically used for GERD treatment but rather for conditions like stomach cancer or severe peptic ulcer disease. Option C - Esophageal banding: This procedure involves placing a band around the esophagus, typically used to treat esophageal varices in patients with portal hypertension, not for GERD. Option D - 270-degree Nissen fundoplication: Also known as Toupet fundoplication, this procedure involves a partial (270 degrees) wrap of the stomach around the esophagus. questions.question: Which nerve is most commonly injured during indirect inguinal hernia surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Ilioinguinal nerve Explanation: The most commonly injured nerve during open inguinal hernia surgery is the ilioinguinal nerve, often leading to chronic pain as a complication. The most common nerve injured in: Open repair: Ilio-inguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve. Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve. questions.question: A patient underwent surgery for pilonidal sinus, which type of flap is used in this surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rhomboid flap Explanation: The Rhomboid flap is often used in pilonidal sinus surgery, especially when excision of the sinus results in a defect that requires tissue advancement to close. This flap allows for tension-free closure and ensures the area is adequately covered, helping to prevent recurrence of the sinus. Pilonidal sinuses are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair. Acquired Condition: Pilonidal sinuses are now considered acquired rather than congenital. Causes: Friction and shearing forces between the skin folds can cause loose hairs to penetrate the skin. Movement of the skin folds may create suction, pulling hair into the skin and forming a chronically infected track, which can develop secondary tracks with discharging openings. Clinical Presentation: Demographics: More common in men, typically presenting after puberty and before age 40, prevalent in individuals with dark, coarse hair. Symptoms: Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine. History of recurring abscesses, which may burst spontaneously or require incision. Treatment Options: Treatment Type Description Conservative Treatment For mild cases: cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance. Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser in less complex cases. questions.question: A 54-year-old male with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumoperitoneum is noted on X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Esophageal perforation Explanation: Esophageal perforation , particularly Boerhaave’s syndrome , is the most likely diagnosis. The patient’s history of multiple episodes of vomiting, binge drinking, and heavy meals, combined with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, strongly suggests a rupture of the esophagus. (Boerhaave’s syndrome) Boerhaave's syndrome is characterized by spontaneous esophageal perforation due to forceful vomiting. Key features include severe chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema. Esophageal perforation Definition A breach in the esophageal wall leads to leakage and increased morbidity and mortality Causes Iatrogenic injury, spontaneous (Boerhaave's syndrome), foreign bodies, corrosive substances, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal cancer Symptoms Varies by cause and location: Iatrogenic (recent instrumentation) Boerhaave's (vomiting, chest pain, emphysema) Cervical (neck pain, etc.) Diagnosis Imaging: Chest X-ray, contrast swallow studies, CT scan Management Seal perforation, ensure drainage, supportive measures (nutrition, cardiorespiratory support, sepsis control) Conservative Management: Suitable for stable patients: antibiotics, nil by mouth, observation Endoscopic Interventions: Visualization, retrieval, sealing with clips/stents, nasogastric tube placement Surgical Intervention: Required for significant sepsis, large perforations, pleural involvement, delayed presentation Surgical Options: Primary repair, controlled fistula creation, esophageal diversion, esophagectomy (rare) Incorrect Options: Mediastinal air leak (Option A) can be a result of various causes, including trauma or infections, but the patient’s history and symptoms make esophageal perforation more likely. Pneumoperitoneum (Option C) refers to air in the peritoneal cavity, often due to a perforated abdominal viscus, such as a perforated ulcer. However, the patient's presentation are more consistent with esophageal perforation. Peptic ulcer (Option D) can cause abdominal pain and potentially lead to perforation, but it typically does not cause chest pain radiating to the shoulder or the presence of pneumoperitoneum as seen in this case.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy?

questions.question: A 60-year-old male patient presents with a left groin swelling for a few years, which increases in size on standing and decreases when lying down. On examination, the swelling shows a positive cough impulse. What is the appropriate management?

options.D: Reduction of contents, repair defects and reinforcement with mesh

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Reduction of contents, repair defect and reinforcement with mesh Explanation: The patient's presentation with a groin swelling that increases in size on standing, decreases when lying down, and shows a positive cough impulse is indicative of an inguinal hernia . Thus, the most appropriate management for this patient is reduction of contents, repair of the defect, and reinforcement with mesh . Management of Inguinal Hernia: Surgical Approaches: Herniotomy : (Option B) It involves excising and closing the hernia sac Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele. In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates. Hernioplasty : Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh. Herniorrhaphy : (Option C) Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures Techniques: Bassini's Repair: Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair. Higher recurrence rates. Shouldice Repair involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's. Modified Shouldice : A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement. Anterior Tension-Free Repair: Lichtenstein Repair : Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. Open Preperitoneal Repair: Stoppa Repair : (Option D) Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia Laparoscopic Hernia Repair: Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair TEP TAPP Procedure Surgery done above the peritoneum Surgery done beneath the peritoneum Advantages Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications. Reduced risk of adhesions. Larger working space Better visualisation Disadvantages Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging. A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity. Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP. Incision and drainage (Option A) are typically used in cases of abscess or infection, which isn't the case here since the swelling is consistent with a hernia, not an infection.

questions.question: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach's triangle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Vas deferens Explanation: The vas deferens do not form a boundary of Hesselbach's triangle. It passes through the inguinal canal and is located posterior to the inguinal ligament, but it is not part of the triangle's boundaries. Hesselbach’s Triangle: A weak spot in the abdominal wall, where direct inguinal hernias occur. Covered only by the transversalis fascia and external oblique aponeurosis. Susceptible to herniation, especially in elderly patients or those with increased abdominal pressure. Boundaries: Lateral border : Inferior epigastric vessels (Option A) Medial border : Rectus abdominis muscle (Option C) Inferior border : Inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament) (Option D) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1066

questions.question: What is the type of hernia in which the internal organ forms a portion of the wall of the hernia sac?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sliding hernia Explanation: A sliding hernia occurs when a part of an internal organ, such as the colon or bladder, forms part of the wall of the hernia sac. Sliding hernia (Hernia-En-Glissade): It occurs when a portion of the peritoneum that normally lines the abdominal cavity slides through the hernia defect, bringing a partially retroperitoneal organ. More common in males, particularly the elderly (Option A ruled out) and frequently occurs on the left side , where the sigmoid colon is the most common content, not the appendix. (Option D ruled out) The posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera (commonly bowel), not the anterior wall. (Option B ruled out) Clinical presentation: Patients typically present with a reducible swelling in the groin or lower abdomen that worsens on standing due to gravity. Gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation and incomplete bowel emptying are common, indicating bowel involvement. Managed surgically by repairing or closing the defect , but associated with a higher risk of bowel injury due to the involvement of the viscera in the hernia sac. questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of epigastric pain for 1 day. On examination, his heart rate is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. There is tenderness, guarding, and rigidity on palpation. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, what is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hollow viscus perforation Explanation: The clinical presentation and the x-ray findings that show free air under the diaphragm, which is a classic sign of perforation, suggest hollow viscus perforation. A hollow viscus perforation occurs when there is a rupture or hole in a hollow organ (such as the stomach, small intestine, large intestine, or duodenum), allowing its contents to spill into the peritoneal cavity. This leads to peritonitis, a potentially life-threatening condition. Clinical features: Acute onset of severe abdominal pain , often described as sharp or stabbing. Generalized peritonitis : Tenderness and guarding over the entire abdomen. Rigidity (board-like abdomen). Tachycardia is due to pain and a systemic response to infection. Hypotension due to septic shock or fluid loss into the peritoneum. Nausea and vomiting are common & fever may develop as a sign of infection. Causes: Peptic ulcer perforation (most common cause, especially in duodenum). Trauma (e.g., stab or gunshot wounds). Diverticulitis leads to colonic perforation. Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn’s disease). Appendicitis that progresses to rupture. Foreign body ingestion leads to injury or

questions.question: During laparoscopic surgery, while inserting the trocar, which of the following is most prone to injury?

options.C: Both superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Both superior and inferior epigastric arteries Explanation: Both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries are at the highest risk during trocar placement due to their superficial and relatively consistent anatomical location in the anterior abdominal wall. The superior and inferior epigastric arteries run vertically within the posterior rectus sheath along the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle . This creates a high-risk zone for injury during trocar insertion, especially in the lower abdomen . The superior epigastric artery descends from the internal thoracic artery , while the inferior epigastric artery ascends from the external iliac artery . These arteries anastomose within the rectus muscle. Their consistent anatomical location and superficial course within the anterior abdominal wall make them particularly vulnerable to injury when a trocar is placed incorrectly. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th Edition, Page 1127 Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 10th Edition, Page 1501

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray shows air under the diaphragm. The patient is taken up for surgery, and an ileal perforation is noted intraoperatively with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy Explanation: Given the gross contamination with enteric and purulent contents, faecal diversion via ileostomy is usually recommended. This helps to prevent further contamination and allows the infected peritoneum to heal while diverting the faecal contents away from the abdomen. Types of Stomas: Type Description Common Uses Reversibility End Colostomy Single opening from the proximal bowel. Often permanent. Used when the distal bowel is removed or left in place, e.g., Hartmann's procedure Often permanent Loop Ileostomy Loop of the bowel is brought to the surface, and an incision is made Temporary diversion, especially in emergencies, and easily reversible Usually temporary Double-barrel Colostomy Two stomas are created: one for faecal output and one for mucus discharge Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula Can be temporary Permanent Ileostomy Terminal ileum is brought to the surface after a colectomy Used when reconnection is not planned, often after total proctocolectomy for conditions like FAP Permanent Incorrect Options: Resection and anastomosis (Option A) is typically used in cases of multiple perforations , malignancy , suspected gangrene , or if there is significant tissue loss. It is not recommended in cases with severe peritoneal contamination , as the risk of infection, abscess formation, and anastomotic leak is high. Primary repair (Option B) is typically reserved for small perforations with minimal contamination and no signs of peritonitis. Omental patch closure (Option D) : While duodenal perforations are often treated with an omentum patch without resection, ileal perforations with significant contamination generally require more aggressive management, such as an ileostomy, to prevent sepsis and further complications.

questions.question: A 60-year-old female presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the abdomen for 1.5 years. She has a history of midline surgery. On examination, the swelling is 4 cm and is reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planning to undergo fascial closure with mesh repair. What is the most likely location of the mesh shown in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Onlay Explanation: This patient most likely has an incisional hernia , which is a common complication following midline surgery, characterised by a bulge or swelling at the site of a previous incision. The treatment often involves fascial closure with mesh repair to reinforce the weakened abdominal wall. The given image shows Onlay mesh repair technique. Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques: Technique Mesh Placement Procedure Advantages Disadvantages Inlay Within the fascial defect itself Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect. It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible. High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure Onlay On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured Technically easier and less invasive. Higher risk of seroma formation , mesh infection, and skin necrosis. Retromuscular Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it Lower recurrence rates , mesh well incorporated into tissues More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles. Preperitoneal Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath. Peritoneum is separated from the posterior rectus sheath; mesh is placed in this space, and the peritoneum is closed over it. Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions. Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.question: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appeared cyanotic, with increased breathing work. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. A chest x-ray is given in the image. questions.question: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamocolumnar junction located more proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Sliding hernia Explanation: Sliding hernia is the most likely cause of the squamocolumnar junction being located more proximally than normal. This condition involves the upward displacement of the gastroesophageal junction into the thorax, which can result in the squamocolumnar junction appearing higher during an endoscopic examination. Hiatus Hernia: Condition in which the abdominal contents pass through the hiatal opening of the diaphragm into the mediastinum. Types Description Type I/Sliding Hiatus Hernia The most common type. The gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach slide up through the diaphragm. Type II/Paraesophageal Hiatus Hernia Part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm next to the oesophagus. The gastroesophageal junction remains in place. Type III/Mixed Hiatus Hernia Combines features of both sliding and paraesophageal hernias. Type IV Involves viscera other than the stomach in the hernial sac, like the colon. Incorrect Options: Achalasia cardia (Option A) typically causes failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a dilated esophagus and difficulties with swallowing, but it doesn't affect the position of the squamocolumnar junction. Rolling hernia (Option C) (also called paraesophageal hernias) involves part of the stomach rolling into the chest beside the esophagus, but this does not typically affect the position of the squamocolumnar junction. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) (Option D) is associated with acid reflux and damage to the esophagus but does not cause the squamocolumnar junction to move proximally. Clinical Features: Heartburn, regurgitation of food, chest pain. Diagnosis: Barium swallow X-Ray, Esophageal manometry. Treatment: PPI, Nissen Fundoplication, Hernia repair.

questions.question: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mucinous cystadenoma Explanation: Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity, often caused by a rupture of a mucin-producing tumor like Mucinous cystadenoma. Pseudomyxoma Peritonei (PMP) is a rare, life-threatening condition characterized by progressive peritoneal tumour deposits, mucinous ascites, omental cake, and ovarian involvement. It is most commonly caused by the rupture of a mucinous appendiceal tumour . Symptoms include abdominal distension, anorexia, and bowel dysfunction. Classification: PMP is graded based on cytological atypia in peritoneal deposits: Acellular mucin Low-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei High-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei High-grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei with signet ring cells Treatment: The standard approach is Cytoreductive Surgery (CRS) combined with Hyperthermic Intraperitoneal Chemotherapy (HIPEC) . This extensive surgery, including organ removals, aims for complete tumour clearance. Survival rates after complete cytoreduction are 87% at 5 years and 70% at 10 years. Chemotherapy may be used for high-grade, unresectable cases or post-surgery in high-risk patients. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1352

questions.question: Which of the following is the treatment of choice in a pregnant woman with an anal wart, as shown in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen Explanation: The image suggests a diagnosis of condyloma acuminata , which is the most common sexually transmitted anal disease caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) . Cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen is the treatment of choice for removing anal warts in pregnant women. The advantage of cryotherapy is that it is relatively bloodless, painless, and allows precise control over the depth and extent of freezing. Condylomata Acuminata (Genital Warts): Genital warts are caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) and are transmitted sexually. HPV infection is common, but only a small proportion of infected individuals develop visible warts. HPV types 6 and 11 are the most common causes of genital warts, and these types are not linked to cervical cancer. Genital warts are distinct from ordinary skin warts, as they tend to be softer, moister, and more often pedunculated. In women, warts are typically seen on the vulva and may line the vagina or appear on the cervix. Perianal warts are also common. Treatment Options: Podophyllin is a commonly used topical treatment. It is applied directly to the wart and carefully washed off after about 6 hours. An alternative chemical treatment is imiquimod . If chemical treatments are ineffective, other methods include cryosurgery , electrosurgery , laser ablation , or surgical excision . Circumcision may be recommended in cases of extensive lesions under the foreskin. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1557

questions.question: A 70-year-old male patient who underwent gastrointestinal surgery one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible 12 cm incisional hernia. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.B: Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use
options.C: Advise observation and reassessment in six months

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair Explanation: The gold standard treatment for an incisional hernia is intra-peritoneal onlay mesh repair . Mesh repair is preferred because it significantly reduces the risk of recurrence compared to other methods. An incisional hernia, also known as a post-operative ventral wall hernia , occurs when fascial tissues fail to fuse properly after surgery. Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques: Technique Mesh Placement Procedure Advantages Disadvantages Inlay Within the fascial defect itself Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect. It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible. High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure Onlay On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured Technically easier and less invasive. Higher risk of seroma formation , mesh infection, and skin necrosis. Retromuscular Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it Lower recurrence rates , mesh well incorporated into tissues More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles. Preperitoneal Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath. Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it. Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions. Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears. Incorrect Options: Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use (Option B): An abdominal belt may be prescribed temporarily for support and improved wound healing post-surgery, but it does not treat the hernia itself. Advise observation and reassessment in six months (Option C): This approach is not recommended, as incisional hernias can lead to complications such as strangulation , obstruction , and incarceration if left untreated. Laparoscopic closure without mesh (Option D) is not advisable due to higher recurrence rates associated with this approach. Mesh repair offers a more reliable long-term solution.

questions.question: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Surgical wall repair Explanation: Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the baby is born with the intestines exposed through a hole in the abdominal wall. The most appropriate treatment is surgical wall repair , where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdomen, and the defect is closed. Feature Omphalocele Gastroschisis Definition Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through the base of the umbilicus . Congenital abdominal wall defect is when abdominal contents protrude through a defect typically located to the right of the umbilicus. Covering The herniated organs are covered by two layers: Amnion (outer) and peritoneum (inner) . No membrane covers the exposed organs. Associated conditions Chromosomal abnormalities: Associated with Trisomy 13, 18, and 21. Other congenital malformations affect multiple systems in the following order: cardiovascular> Muscular> gastrointestinal> genitourinary. (Mnemonic: "CM GIGU") Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: Can include hemihypertrophy, macroglossia, visceromegaly, omphalocele, and increased risk of hepatoblastoma. Fewer chromosomal abnormalities compared to omphalocele. Higher risk of intestinal atresia and dysfunction. Prognosis Generally poor due to associated congenital malformations, which are the most common cause of death. Generally better than omphalocele due to fewer associated congenital anomalies. Management Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects. Larger defects may require: Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex ), Porcine small intestinal submucosa -derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis ), Skin flap closure , or Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure . For giant omphaloceles , topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac. Primary closure is typically done under general anesthesia and often requires admission to the NICU for postoperative ventilation. Alternatively, a preformed silo can be placed at the bedside for gradual reduction, sometimes avoiding the need for general anesthesia altogether. Incorrect Options: Wait and watch (Option B) : This approach is not recommended as it can lead to complications such as fluid loss, hypothermia, hypovolemia, sepsis, metabolic acidosis, and necrotizing enterocolitis. Slowly putting it inside (Option C) : While the intestines are gradually pushed back inside during primary closure , this is not a management option by itself. Surgical excision (Option D) is only performed for non-viable bowel followed by anastomosis .

questions.question: Identify the image:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Omphalocele Explanation: The given image shows Omphalocele. Omphalocele is a central abdominal wall defect typically larger than 4 cm in diameter , characterized by an intact membranous sac composed of an outer layer of amnion and an inner layer of peritoneum . Defects smaller than 4 cm are classified as umbilical cord hernias . Associated anomalies: 50% of infants with omphalocele have associated anomalies, including: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome : A combination of gigantism , macroglossia , and an umbilical defect (either hernia or omphalocele). Chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomies 13, 15, 18, and 21 . Other conditions like bladder exstrophy , cloaca , and pentalogy of Cantrell , which includes: Omphalocele Anterior diaphragmatic hernia Sternal cleft Ectopia cordis Intracardiac defects , like ventricular septal defect . Initial management: The presence of an intact omphalocele sac is crucial for initial management. Preventing hypothermia is a primary concern. A comprehensive diagnostic workup is performed to identify associated anomalies. Surgical treatment: Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects. Larger defects may require: Prosthetic patch closure (e.g., Gore-Tex ), Porcine small intestinal submucosa -derived biomaterials (e.g., Surgisis ), Skin flap closure , or Placement of a silo for sequential reduction and staged closure . For giant omphaloceles , topical application of escharotic agents like povidone-iodine (Betadine) ointment or silver nitrate is used to thicken and epithelialize the sac. The overall survival of infants with omphalocele depends largely on their lung maturity and the severity of associated anomalies . Urachal cyst (Option B) is a fluid-filled sac that results from the incomplete closure of the urachus (a remnant of the connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord). It doesn't present as an abdominal wall defect like omphalocele. Umbilical hernia (Option C) occurs when part of the intestine or other abdominal contents protrude through the umbilical opening in the abdominal muscles. It’s usually smaller and has no sac covering the contents, as seen in omphalocele. Umbilical adenoma (Option D) is a benign tumour located in or near the umbilicus, unrelated to abdominal wall defects like omphalocele.

questions.question: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hollow viscus Explanation: Hollow viscus (such as the small and large intestines) is the most commonly affected organ in seat belt injuries. Seat belt injury: The mesentery , a fold of tissue that attaches the intestines to the posterior abdominal wall, is particularly vulnerable in seat belt injuries due to the compressive force of the belt across the abdomen. This can lead to mesenteric tears, avulsions, or hematomas, resulting in internal bleeding or ischemia, which often require surgical intervention to prevent complications like bowel necrosis. The classical seat belt sign refers to a distinctive pattern of bruising or contusion across the abdomen and chest resulting from the force of a seat belt during a car accident. This visible mark is a significant indicator of potential underlying injuries, including damage to internal organs like the mesentery, small intestine, or spine. Management of seat belt-related injuries: FAST is a quick and widely available method to detect intraperitoneal fluid or blood. Computed tomography (CT) scanning offers significant advantages by identifying critical details such as extraluminal air or contrast leakage, which can guide the need for surgical intervention. In cases where spinal injury is suspected, imaging of the entire spine should be conducted to rule out fractures, such as the Chance fracture commonly associated with seat belt injuries. Treatment: Immediate laparotomy. Seat belt syndrome describes the combination of the seat belt sign with associated internal injuries, such as abdominal organ damage or spinal fractures, particularly in the thoracolumbar region.

questions.question: A young patient in the first decade of life presents with grade II splenic injury with no active bleeding. What is the management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Conservative Explanation: In the case of a grade II splenic injury without active bleeding, the management is generally conservative. This involves admission to the ICU for close monitoring, with repeated clinical assessments and possibly serial imaging to ensure there is no progression of injury or delayed bleeding. The goal is to preserve the spleen, thus avoiding the complications associated with splenectomy, such as OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection) American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale Grade I (Minor Injury): Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area. Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding. Grade II: Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area. Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter. Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels. Grade III: Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma. Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding. Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels. Grade IV: Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen. Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss. Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule Grade V (Severe Injury): Completely shattered spleen. Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularization of the spleen. Management: Management of blunt trauma focuses on vigorous resuscitation. For hemodynamically stable patients with minor splenic injuries , non-operative management (NOM) (conservative) is the preferred approach. Splenectomy is recommended for severe injuries where bleeding control is prioritized over spleen preservation. In cases with active bleeding, splenic angiography and embolization can be used to avoid splenectomy, but this should not delay laparotomy in hemodynamically unstable patients. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1224

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for an adult male patient with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Fistula in ano Explanation: A fistula in ano is a common cause of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening near the perianal region. It often results from a previous perianal abscess that has developed into a chronic fistulous tract. Fistula-in-Ano A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women. Causes Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis. Associated Conditions: Crohn’s disease Tuberculosis Lymphogranuloma venereum Actinomycosis Rectal duplication Foreign bodies Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula) Clinical features Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief. Previous history of Anorectal abscess Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening). Classifications: Low-level fistulas open into the anal canal below the internal ring. High-level fistulas open into the anal canal at or above the internal ring. Simple fistula without extensions Complex fistula with extensions. Parks classification Type 1 Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%) Type 2 Trans- sphincteric (25%) Type 3 Supra- sphincteric (4%) Type 4 Extra- sphincteric (1%) Incorrect Options: Hemorrhoids (Option A) typically present with bleeding during defecation but do not produce purulent discharge. Pilonidal sinus (Option B) typically presents in the sacrococcygeal region and may involve purulent discharge, but is not commonly associated with blood-tinged drainage. Perianal abscess (Option C) is an acute condition characterized by pain, swelling, and often fever, with purulent drainage, but would not typically cause intermittent discharge over time without other symptoms of infection.

It causes difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and often results in a progressive esophageal dilation above the constricted LES. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing Clinical Features Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids. Regurgitation Halitosis Chest Pain Weight Loss Investigations: Esophageal Manometry Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A) Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg). Incomplete LES relaxation. Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body. Periodic contractions with

questions.question: A patient underwent bronchoscopy, during the procedure a perforation occurred at 25 cm. Which structure is most likely to be damaged?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Arch of aorta Explanation: In the given scenario of perforation at 25 cm , the arch of the aorta is most likely to be damaged, as this is the region where the esophagus is compressed by the aorta and left bronchus. Constrictions of Esophagus: 0 cm - Incisor teeth (start of the esophagus). 15 cm - Cricopharyngeal constriction (upper esophageal sphincter). 25 cm - Aortic and bronchial constriction (due to the aorta and left bronchus). 40 cm - Diaphragmatic constriction (at the esophageal hiatus, lower esophageal sphincter). Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1107

questions.question: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Resection and Anastomosis Explanation: The given image shows Resection and Anastomosis. This procedure involves the removal of a diseased or damaged segment of the bowel (resection) and then surgically joining the healthy ends of the remaining bowel (anastomosis). It's commonly performed in cases such as: Meckel’s diverticulum with an unhealthy base Transverse mesentery tear Small intestinal duplication Enterogenous cysts Primary closure of perforation : Typically involves suturing a hole or perforation in the gastrointestinal tract, usually performed in cases of bowel perforation. Ileostomy : A surgical procedure where the end of the ileum (small intestine) is brought to the surface of the abdomen to create an opening (stoma) for waste to exit. It may be used in cases of inflammatory bowel disease or after bowel resections. Resection alone : This refers to the removal of part of the gastrointestinal tract without performing an anastomosis. It might be used when a portion of the bowel is removed due to a tumor, but reconnection isn't necessary or feasible at the time.

questions.question: A young female presents with pain and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray shows intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Strangulated Femoral Hernia Explanation: The swelling lateral and below the pubic tubercle and the presence of intestinal obstruction are most likely indicative of a strangulated femoral hernia. In an indirect inguinal hernia (Option B) , the neck of the hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle. In contrast, the neck of the hernia in a femoral hernia is located below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The femoral ring and canal are relatively rigid, which increases the risk of strangulation in these cases. Femoral Hernia: A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall. Location: Appears as a bulge in the upper thigh, just below the groin crease. Demographics: More common in women, especially older and overweight females. Risk: Higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias. Symptoms: Lump in the groin or upper thigh, which may be painless or painful. Discomfort when standing, lifting, or straining. Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain if the hernia becomes incarcerated or strangulated. Adhesions (Option A): While adhesions can cause intestinal obstruction, they do not typically present with swelling. Appendicular Mass (Option D): An appendicular mass can cause swelling but is usually located in the right iliac fossa, not lateral and below the pubic tubercle. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1071,1072

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation . Radiological imaging shows a blind pouch at the level of the pharynx. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: in the esophageal wall, leading to the outpouching of the mucosa through weakened areas. This can cause symptoms like dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation, and bad breath (halitosis). Incorrect Options: Option B - Achalasia Cardia : Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus where the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, causing difficulty in food passage and esophageal dilation. Symptoms include dysphagia, regurgitation, and sometimes weight loss. While lobar pneumonia could potentially result from aspiration due to dysphagia, it is not a defining feature of achalasia. Option C - CA Esophagus (Esophageal Cancer): Esophageal cancer can lead to dysphagia, weight loss, and other symptoms. However, lobar pneumonia and consolidation are not directly related to esophageal cancer. CA Esophagus does not explain these radiological findings. Option D - GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease): GERD can cause symptoms like dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. However, lobar pneumonia and consolidation are not typical consequences of GERD. These symptoms might arise due to chronic aspiration of stomach contents, leading to pneumonia, but GERD alone does not explain the presence of lobar pneumonia. Reference: .

questions.question: A 60-year-old man, a smoker, presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue. He is known to be anemic and his sister had a history of endometrial cancer. The physician is considering appropriate colorectal cancer screening methods for this patient. Which screening method should be recommended for colorectal malignancy in this patient?

options.C: Check for occult blood in stool

questions.explanation: screening method for colorectal malignancy, especially in individuals with risk factors such as a family history of colorectal cancer and a personal history of anemia. Colonoscopy allows for direct visualization of the entire colon and rectum, and it can both detect and remove precancerous growths (polyps) during the same procedure. Incorrect options: Option A - Barium enema: Barium enema is not a method for colorectal cancer screening. Option C - Check for occult blood in stool: Occult blood can be an indicator of gastrointestinal bleeding. While fecal occult blood test (FOBT) is a screening method, it is not the most sensitive test and may require repeated testing. Option D - Flexible sigmoidoscopy yearly: Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a screening method that involves examining the lower part of the colon and rectum using a flexible sigmoidoscope. While it can be effective, it only examines a portion of the colon. Colonoscopy provides a more comprehensive examination of the entire colon and is recommended every 10 years for colorectal cancer screening.
