questions.explanation: foods (e.g., salted and smoked meats), low intake of fruits and vegetables N-nitroso compounds are formed from nitrates in high-salt and smoked foods, Similar to tobacco smoke Lifestyle habits Smoking, alcohol, poor food preparation (smoked, salted), lack of refrigeration, contaminated drinking water, low socioeconomic status Infectious Causes H- pylori infection: M/c infectious cause of gastric cancer. Mechanism : Chronic inflammation leading to atrophic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia, and carcinoma Polyps Adenomatous polyps (risk of malignancy) In multiple polyps, the largest one is excised, and biopsy from others is taken. Hereditary factors E-cadherin (CDH1) gene mutation (hereditary diffuse gastric cancer) (Statement B) Hereditary cancer syndromes Li- Fraumeni syndrome Medications Proton pump inhibitors (long-term use creates low-acid environment achlorhydria; Risk for H. pylori colonisation) Other risk factors Gastric ulcers, pernicious anaemia (achlorhydria), obesity, Epstein-Barr virus, prior abdominal irradiation (for testicular cancer or Hodgkin’s lymphoma), prior gastric surgery, male sex Wnt signalling pathway defect is seen in intestinal-type gastric carcinoma (Statement C) : The Wnt signalling pathway plays a crucial role in developing intestinal-type gastric carcinoma. Dysregulation of this pathway can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and tumour formation. Protective factors of Gastric carcinoma: Fruits and vegetables, especially citrus fruits, help decrease the risk of the disease. Exercise helps control the weight and improves muscle mass and overall health. Antioxidant supplements help, too. ( beta carotene, vitamin C, vitamin A, selenium) Cessation of smoking is also necessary. It is mostly hereditary (Statement A) : There are certain genetic factors that can increase the risk of developing gastric cancer, but the majority of cases are not directly linked to hereditary factors. Depth of cancer has no role in prognosis (Statement D) : The depth of cancer invasion, known as tumour staging, is an important prognostic factor in gastric carcinoma. Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1219-1221.

questions.question: A patient presented with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and was found to have pancreatic necrosis. Which of the following are included in the management of the condition? Antibiotics IV IV fluids Culture MRI Assisted drainage Laparotomy
questions.explanation: diffuse or focal area of non-viable parenchyma. Pathogenesis: It involves peripancreatic fat lysis, leading to an acute necrotic collection (ANC) with fluid and necrotic material, developing a defined inflammatory capsule, and evolving into walled-off necrosis (WON). Types: Sterile (initial stage) and Infected. CECT scan: An absence of parenchymal enhancement. Culture and Sensitivity: Aspirated fluid is sent for culture and sensitivity. (Statement 3) Management: Supportive measures (IV fluids and stabilisation) (Statement 2) Sterile necrotic material should not be drained or interfered with. Signs of sepsis (purulent aspirate) : Drainage (endoscopic ultrasound-guided is preferred) of the infected fluid. (Statement 5) Antibiotic therapy (Statement 1) Pancreatic necrosectomy (laparotomy). (Statement 6) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (Statement 4) is not typically used in the management of pancreatic necrosis. It may be used later in the course of the disease to assess the extent of necrosis or complications. CT scan is preferred. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1274-1275.

questions.question: What is the most prevalent condition that leads to the occurrence of heartburn and chest pain in a patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer D) Esophagitis Explanation: Esophagitis, characterized by inflammation of the esophagus, presents symptoms such as chest pain, heartburn, acid regurgitation, and difficulty swallowing. Treatment typically involves Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs). Barrett's esophagus (Option A) In the lower part or distal oesophagus, the Squamous mucosa is replaced by columnar mucosa, and there is a long history of heartburn. Pneumonia (Option B) Pneumonia is an infection that affects one or both lungs. The air sacs/alveoli of the lungs are filled up with fluid or pus. Myocardial infarction (Option C) is caused by decreased supply of blood flow to a portion of the myocardium. Clinical features include chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck, dyspnea, sweating, heartburn, fatigue, and weakness. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 294- 296

questions.question: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Foreign body in the esophagus Explanation: On Chest Xray foreign body in the oesophagus is characterized by - On PA view: Flat surface of the coin On Lateral view: Edge of the coin Foreign body in the trachea (Option A) Tracheal foreign bodies are usually seen in the sagittal orientation on AP view due to the airflow pattern. It presents with cough, stridor, or wheezing rather than pure dysphagia. Foreign body in lungs (Option C) More common in aspiration, affecting the right main bronchus. Symptoms include sudden onset cough, wheezing, respiratory distress, or asymmetric breath sounds. It may show air trapping on expiratory films. Foreign body in pleura (Option D) Foreign bodies do not typically enter the pleural space unless there is penetrating trauma. Pleural foreign bodies would cause pneumothorax or hemothorax, not dysphagia.

questions.question: What is the most appropriate next course of action in managing a male patient, aged 40, who presents with widespread abdominal pain and has a confirmed history of Crohn's disease, as well as rigidity and guarding observed during a physical examination, with ileal perforation being detected on imaging?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy Explanation: Ileal perforation in Crohn’s disease is a life-threatening complication that requires immediate surgical intervention. Primary repair vs. Ileostomy: Primary repair is not ideal due to inflamed, friable tissue and high recurrence risk. An ileostomy is preferred to divert faecal contents and allow healing before later reversal. Without surgery, the patient risks septic shock, multi-organ failure, and death. Antibiotics and NPO (Option A) Supportive care alone is insufficient for a perforation. Antibiotics help control infection but do not treat the perforation. Surgery is mandatory to remove the perforated segment and control peritonitis. Upper GI endoscopy (Option B) Not useful for small bowel (ileal) disease. Contraindicated in perforation due to risk of further bowel injury. CT abdomen (Option D) Imaging is already done, confirming perforation. Further delay increases morbidity and mortality. The next step is definitive surgical intervention, not additional imaging. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1330-1334

questions.question: A 34-year-old male presented with a painless mass in the right inguinal region. On examination, there is a cough impulse on the index finger. The swelling reaches the scrotum and is reduced completely by pressing it through the deep inguinal ring with a gurgling sound. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Indirect inguinal hernia Explanation: Origin: Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels, entering the deep inguinal ring. Path: Passes through the inguinal canal, sometimes reaching the scrotum. Complete reduction through deep inguinal ring : Classic for an indirect hernia. Gurgling sound: Indicates the presence of bowel loops within the hernia sac. Femoral hernia (Option A) Located below the inguinal ligament, more common in women, and does not extend into the scrotum. No gurgling sound or reducibility through the deep ring. Direct inguinal hernia (Option B): Bulges through Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Does not extend into the scrotum and is usually more diffuse, not reducible through the deep ring. Umbilical hernia (Option D) Occurs at the umbilicus, unrelated to the inguinal region. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 745,746

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a 40-year-old patient who has experienced the passage of mucus and blood in their stool, with inflammation predominantly observed in the rectum during sigmoidoscopy, and the presence of crypt abscess detected during biopsy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ulcerative colitis: Explanation: Features Ulcerative colitis Crohn’s disease Location Limited to colon and rectum Can involve any part of the GI tract Distribution Diffuse lesion Patchy, with skip lesions. Gross appearance Mucosal erythema and granularity Broad-based ulcers with a continuous pattern Pseudopolyps Mucosal atrophy Smooth, continuous inflammation Transmural inflammation Aphthous ulcers Cobblestone appearance Fistulae, strictures, abscesses Creeping fat (mesenteric fat wrapping) Complications Toxic megacolon Colonic dilation Mucosal bridges Strictures Fistulae Irritable bowel syndrome (Option B) presents with features of abdominal discomfort, bloating, and altered bowel habits (diarrhoea or constipation). No blood in stool, no crypt abscesses, and no inflammation on biopsy. Crohn's disease (Option C) presents with features of skip lesions, transmural inflammation, and non-caseating granulomas. It can affect any part of the GI tract (mouth to anus), usually sparing the rectum. Fistulas, strictures, cobblestone appearance on endoscopy. Pseudomembranous colitis (Option D) presents with profuse, watery diarrhoea after recent antibiotic use. Pseudomembranes (yellow plaques) are seen on colonoscopy. No crypt abscesses and inflammation is not limited to the rectum.

questions.question: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put in a lithotomy position, and the opening is located at the 11 o’clock position, 2 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening, and where does the internal opening start?

options.A: 12 o’clock and at the external anal sphincter
options.B: 11 o’clock and at the internal anal sphincter
options.D: 6 o’clock and crypt of the dentate line

questions.explanation: Correct answer B) 11 o’clock and at the internal anal sphincter Explanation: Goodsall's Rule: Anterior External Opening: If the fistula's external opening is in the anterior half of the anus (front side), the fistula usually follows a direct path to the internal opening within the anus. Posterior External Opening: If the fistula's external opening is in the posterior half of the anus (back side), the fistula typically follows a curved path, forming a horseshoe shape, and opens internally at the midline of the posterior anus. The exception to Goodsall's Rule: Anterior external opening more than 3 cm from the Anus: If the external opening is located more than 3 cm away from the anal margin (anterior side), the fistula is likely to track to the posterior midline, rather than following a direct path as Goodsall's Rule would typically suggest. 12 o’clock and at the external anal sphincter (Option A): The external sphincter is not the primary site for fistula origin; fistulas originate from the crypts in the dentate line . 11 o’clock, and at internal anal sphincter (Option C), does not follow Goodsall’s Rule ; posterior fistulae track to the midline (6 o’clock) . 9 o’clock and at the anal verge (Option D): This does not match the typical fistula pattern based on the location given.

questions.question: What is the most probable outcome for the patient after undergoing gastrectomy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Vitamin B12 deficiency Explanation: Gastrectomy (partial or total removal of the stomach) significantly affects nutrient absorption , particularly Vitamin B12 , due to the loss of intrinsic factors. Intrinsic factor (IF) , produced by gastric parietal cells , is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum . Gastrectomy removes parietal cells , leading to intrinsic factor deficiency and causing impaired vitamin B12 absorption . This leads to pernicious anemia , presenting with megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, and glossitis . Management: Lifelong B12 supplementation (IM or high-dose oral). Folic acid deficiency (Option A) Folate is absorbed in the proximal jejunum , which remains intact after gastrectomy. It is not a direct consequence of gastrectomy unless there is associated malnutrition . Gastric ulcer (Option C) Gastrectomy reduces acid secretion , lowering the risk of gastric ulcers . However, marginal ulcers may develop at anastomotic sites in certain procedures. Constipation (Option D) Gastrectomy does not directly cause constipation; patients may experience dumping syndrome or diarrhoea instead. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24096753/

questions.question: What is the diagnosis for a patient who exhibits symptoms of dysphagia, experiencing pain behind the breastbone, and regurgitation accompanied by coughing following meals?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Esophageal diverticula Explanation: Esophageal diverticula are outpouches or pockets that develop in the wall of the esophagus. These diverticula can interfere with the normal passage of food, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and regurgitation. Esophageal Diverticula : Type Location Cause Symptoms Diagnosis Treatment Zenker’s Diverticulum Upper esophagus (pharyngoesophageal junction) Cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction (pulsion) Dysphagia, regurgitation, halitosis, aspiration Barium swallow (posterior outpouching) Diverticulectomy or endoscopic myotomy Mid-Esophageal Diverticulum Mid-esophagus (middle third) Traction from mediastinal inflammation (e.g., TB) Usually, asymptomatic or mild dysphagia Barium swallow (mid-esophageal outpouching) No treatment unless symptomatic Epiphrenic Diverticulum Lower oesophagus (above LES) Esophageal motility disorders (e.g., achalasia) Dysphagia, regurgitation, nocturnal cough Barium swallow (outpouching near LES) Surgical myotomy or diverticulectomy, if needed Brown Patterson Kelly syndrome (Option A) presents with iron deficiency anaemia, esophageal webs, and dysphagia . It does not cause regurgitation or retrosternal pain . Achalasia (Option B) presents with progressive dysphagia for both solids and liquids. LES fails to relax, leading to the bird’s beak sign on the barium swallow. It does not usually cause significant regurgitation with coughing after meals. Reflux esophagitis (Option D) presents with heartburn, acid regurgitation, and erosions due to GERD . Dysphagia occurs later due to stricture formation , not an early symptom. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1126,1127

questions.question: In a patient with ascites visiting your clinic for diagnostic paracentesis, you opt for a midline approach to remove the fluid. Which of the following size needles is used during this procedure?
questions.explanation: This size needle is optimal for fluid aspiration, as it is large enough to allow effective drainage of ascitic fluid while minimizing tissue trauma. It also provides an efficient rate of fluid removal, which is important for collecting a sufficient volume of ascitic fluid for diagnostic analysis. 14 gauge (Option A) : A 14-gauge needle is generally too large for diagnostic paracentesis. It is more suited for therapeutic procedures when large volumes of fluid need to be removed quickly. Using a 14-gauge needle for diagnostic purposes may cause unnecessary discomfort and tissue injury. 17 gauge (Option C) : While a 17-gauge needle is technically usable, it is less common in practice. The 16-gauge needle is generally preferred for diagnostic paracentesis because it provides a better balance between fluid aspiration efficiency and minimal tissue damage. 22 gauge (Option D) : A 22-gauge needle is too small for diagnostic paracentesis. It would not allow for efficient aspiration of sufficient fluid volume, making it less ideal for this procedure. Reference: Diagnostic and therapeutic abdominal paracentesis - PMC

questions.question: A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. A barium swallow was performed, and the following image was shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: disorder of the esophagus. In barium swallow, we can observe a “corkscrew esophagus' ' Clinically, chest pain and dysphagia, predominantly while eating spicy food, are the symptoms. Sacculations and pseudo diverticula can also be seen. Infectious esophagitis (Option A) In infectious esophagitis, linear, regular plaque-like lesions can be seen on the contrast X-ray. Barette’s esophagus (Option C) In Barette's esophagus, the X-ray does not show any specific findings. Esophageal stricture (Option D) Barium meal shows a narrow esophagus with a shoulder-like appearance Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition), Page 1125, 1126

questions.question: The provided barium swallow indicates
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Achalasia cardia Explanation: Achalasia cardia is a massively dilated esophagus. It has a narrow distal end. Radiologically we can observe a bird beak sign as seen in the given image. A patient suffering from achalasia cardia has more difficulty swallowing liquids than solids. Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B) A corkscrew sign is seen in the diffuse esophagus. Nutcracker esophagus (Option C) The nutcracker esophagus also shows a corkscrew sign similar to the diffuse esophageal spasm. Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter (Option D) It does not show a bird beak sign, and hence, it is an incorrect choice. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition), Page 1121, 1123

questions.question: Which of the following conditions has a barium enema as shown in the picture below?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Diverticulosis Diverticulosis is the outpouching of the colon wall. In a barium swallow, the contrast x ray shows an outpouching filled with barium as seen in the image it presents as a “ Saw tooth appearance ” It is most commonly seen in the sigmoid colon. Multiple colonic polyps (Option A) Colonic polyps appear as single polypoid lesions in the radiograph. It does not present a Sawtooth appearance. Ulcerative colitis (Option B) A smooth colon with no haustrations “Lead pipe colon” is seen in the radiograph. Irritable bowel Syndrome (Option D) Saw tooth appearance is not seen in irritable bowel syndrome. Diverticulosis Definition Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon. Etiology Diet: A low-fiber diet increases colon pressure. Age: More common in those over 60. Genetics: Family history may increase risk. Pathophysiology Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge. Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula.

questions.question: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in the above condition is FAP ( familial adenomatous polyposis) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP): Caused Autosomal dominant mutation in the APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene on chromosome 5q21. 100% risk of colorectal cancer in those with APC gene mutation. 80% of cases are from positive family history. Clinical Features: Numerous (>100) colorectal adenomatous polyps, typically develop in adolescence or early adulthood. Rectal bleeding, diarrhoea, abdominal pain Extracolonic manifestations : Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), desmoid tumours, upper gastrointestinal polyps, epidermoid cyst (Gardner syndrome) Increased risk of other cancers: duodenal, thyroid, brain (medulloblastoma), hepatoblastoma Diagnosis: Colonoscopy showing >100 polyps and biopsy showing an adenomatous variety of polyp. Treatment: The aim of Surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer. Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis. Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA) Total proctocolectomy and end-ileostomy. Crohn's disease (Option A) While it can cause rectal bleeding, it doesn't typically present with numerous polyps throughout the colon. Lynch syndrome/Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) (Option C) This condition increases cancer risk but doesn't usually cause numerous polyps. The average age of onset is later than FAP. Juvenile polyposis syndrome (Option D) This can cause multiple polyps, but they are typically hamartomatous rather than adenomatous, fewer in number than FAP.

questions.question: During a routine check-up, an elderly male was discovered to have a rectal mass during a digital rectal examination, indicating the possibility of rectal carcinoma. Despite normal bowel habits, the next course of action for managing this patient should be:
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Full colonoscopy and biopsy Explanation A full colonoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis of rectal carcinoma and to rule out the presence of any synchronous lesions. If any lesions are identified, a biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis and determine the stage and the characteristics of the tumor. Investigations and Diagnosis of Rectal Carcinoma Digital Rectal Examination : Used to assess the size, consistency (hard), shape (Irregular), and mobility (mobile, tethered, or fixed). A vaginal examination is recommended for women to check for involvement of the posterior vaginal wall. Rigid Sigmoidoscopy : Outpatient procedure for visualising the neoplasm and obtaining biopsies Biopsy and Histological Analysis : Crucial for confirming the diagnosis and distinguishing rectal carcinoma from conditions that may mimic it, such as inflammatory strictures, granulomas, and benign adenomas. Staging Investigations : CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Local pelvic imaging with MRI and/or endoluminal ultrasonography provides detailed information about local tumour spread, including infiltration into surrounding tissues and lymph node involvement. Colonoscopy : Essential for most patients to rule out synchronous tumours elsewhere in the colon. Techniques like "dye spray" colonoscopy help differentiate benign from malignant lesions based on mucosal 'pit patterns'. Proximal adenomas can be removed during the procedure; finding synchronous carcinomas may alter surgical strategy. CT Colonography or Barium Enema : Alternatives to colonoscopy if full visualization of the colon is not possible due to stenosing cancer. CT scan of the abdomen (Option A) CT scan of the abdomen is useful in determining the size, location and staging of the tumour. Rigid sigmoidoscopy and biopsy (Option B) This procedure can only be used to examine the distal portion of the rectum and sigmoid colon but not the entire colon. Barium enema (Option D) This technique was used earlier but now is vastly replaced by colonoscopy as it is a better diagnostic procedure. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1406

questions.question: A 30-year-old female presented with a low-grade fever of 1-week duration associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. Barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Ileocaecal TB Explanation: In the barium study of the ileum in the case of ileocaecal TB, these are the signs that can be seen in the narrowing of the terminal ileum. Thickening of the ileocecal valve and the thickening of the cecal walls, the cecum appears as a conical shape. In later stages, the ileum is fixed and rigid. Ileocecal Tuberculosis: Feature Details Definition A form of abdominal tuberculosis affecting the ileocecal region, the most common site of gastrointestinal TB. Why the Ileocecal Region? Rich in lymphoid tissue, slow transit time, and increased uptake of tubercle bacilli. Common Symptoms Right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain, weight loss, fever, diarrhoea/constipation, and abdominal mass. Differential Diagnoses Crohn’s disease, appendicitis, colorectal cancer, lymphoma. Physical Examination RLQ tenderness, palpable mass, signs of obstruction (in severe cases). Imaging Findings Ultrasound/CT scan : Bowel wall thickening, lymphadenopathy, ascites, strictures. Endoscopic Findings Colonoscopy : Ulcers, nodularity, strictures in the ileocecal region. Histopathology Caseating granulomas, acid-fast bacilli (AFB) on Ziehl-Neelsen stain. Definitive Diagnosis AFB culture, PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Treatment Anti-TB Therapy (ATT) : Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol (2 months), followed by Rifampicin + Isoniazid (4 months). Indications for Surgery Bowel obstruction, perforation, abscess, stricture, and unresponsiveness to ATT. Surgical Options Limited resection (if necessary), stricturoplasty (for non-resectable strictures). Ulcerative colitis (Option B): Radiologically, ulcerative colitis presents with a contracted, pipe-stem colon and thickened, edematous haustra. Crohn’s disease (Option C): Radiologically, Crohn’s disease is characterised by a cobblestone appearance, making it an incorrect choice. Carcinoma caecum (Option D) In the case of carcinoma of the cecum, you can see apple core deformity on the right side of the right iliac fossa and not at the terminal ileum. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 88 - 91

questions.question: A 35-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with a concern of vomiting blood. He mentions a recent pattern of excessive alcohol consumption. Upon examination, his vital signs are steady, and he has a pale appearance. There are no indications of ongoing bleeding. The results of his liver function tests are within the normal range. To further assess the situation, an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is scheduled. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) Mallory-Weiss tear Explanation: Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal lacerations that occur at the gastroesophageal junction, usually due to severe vomiting or retching. Binge alcohol drinking can lead to forceful vomiting, which may cause these tears. Mallory-Weiss tears are a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding in individuals with a history of alcohol abuse, and they can present with hematemesis. Esophageal varices (Option A) While alcohol abuse can contribute to liver disease, the absence of liver function abnormalities make esophageal varices less likely. Gastric ulcer (Option B) Risk factors like Helicobacter pylori infection or non-steroidal anti inflammatory drug (NSAID) use is usually more significant in developing gastric ulcers. Alcoholic gastritis (Option D) Absence of any liver function abnormalities and considering the presentation with hematemesis, Mallory-Weiss tear is a more probable diagnosis compared to alcoholic gastritis. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page 1235 Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1127-1129

questions.question: Which of the following accurately represents Bormann's classification for gastric carcinoma?

options.A: Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component
options.B: Type II: Ulcerated tumor with infiltrative margins
options.C: Type III: Diffusely infiltrative tumor with linitis plastica appearance
options.D: Type IV: Mucinous carcinoma with extensive peritoneal metastases

questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component: Explanation: Borrman's classification is a pathologic classification system based on the macroscopic appearance of gastric carcinomas. Type I tumours are characterised by a diffuse polypoidal growth pattern. This combination of a predominantly polypoid growth with a small ulcerated area distinguishes Type I gastric carcinomas according to Borrman's classification. Bormann’s Classification of Gastric Carcinoma Bormann Type Macroscopic Appearance Key Features Type I (Polypoid type) Polypoid or fungating mass Well-defined borders , grow into the lumen, minimal invasion into the gastric wall, mand ay have a small ulcerated component . Type II (Ulcerated tumor with distinct borders) Ulcerated lesion with raised margins Clearly defined infiltrative edges , but not deeply penetrating into surrounding tissues. (Option B ruled out) Type III (Ulceroinfiltrative type) (Option C ruled out) Deep ulceration with infiltrative margins Irregular and poorly defined borders , penetrate deeper into the gastric wall, more aggressive than Type II. Type IV (Diffuse/Infiltrative type – Linitis Plastica) (Option D ruled out) Diffuse thickening of the stomach wall Infiltrative growth without a discrete mass , causes "a leather bottle stomach" appearance, commonly associated with signet-ring cell carcinoma . Reference: https://wjso.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12957-016-0805-9

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vomiting. He reports a 2-day history of constipation and bloating. On examination, he appears uncomfortable, and his abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. X-ray reveals dilated loops of the small bowel. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Small bowel obstruction Explanation: Small bowel obstruction is the most likely cause in this case. The patient's acute symptoms, abdominal distension, high-pitched bowel sounds, and dilated loops of small bowel on X-ray is consistent with a mechanical obstruction in the small bowel. Colonic malignancy (Option A) Colonic malignancy can lead to obstruction, but it typically causes a gradual onset of symptoms, such as changes in bowel habits, blood in stool, and weight Loss. Acute pancreatitis (Option C) The presentation of acute pancreatitis often includes epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated serum amylase or lipase levels and may be associated with gallstones or alcohol consumption. Gastric ulcer (Option D) Gastric ulcers are typically associated with symptoms such as epigastric pain, heartburn, and may be exacerbated by eating. Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO) Causes Adhesions (Most common) Malignancy Metastasis Peritoneal carcinomatosis Hernia Crohn's Disease Tb PID Post radiotherapy Cancer Surgeries with High Risk of Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO) Pelvic surgeries (Highest risk) Lower abdominal surgeries Upper abdominal surgeries Malignancies Responsible for SBO Metastasis Peritoneal carcinomatosis Clinical Features of Small Bowel Obstruction: Colicky Abdominal Pain (First symptom): Due to hyperperistalsis in the small intestine caused by intestinal obstruction. Multiple Episodes of Bilious Vomiting Obstipation (Absolute Constipation) Proximal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms: Vomiting Dyselectrolytemia (electrolyte imbalances due to vomiting) Distal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms: Distension (more prominent) Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1381 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 909-912

questions.question: Which of the following findings of colonoscopy is highly malignant?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Multiple flat polyp about 100 Explanation: Among the options you provided, the finding of "Multiple flat polyps about 100" is concerning for a higher risk of malignancy. This is because having a large number of flat polyps (approximately 100) increases the likelihood of some of these polyps being dysplastic or even cancerous. Single pedunculated polyp (Option B) Any polyp has the potential to be cancerous, a single pedunculated polyp, especially if small and without concerning features, is typically considered low risk for malignancy. Multiple pedunculated polyps (Option C) In the context of multiple pedunculated polyps, further evaluation and genetic testing may be warranted to assess the risk of malignancy. Solitary flat polyp (Option D) Flat polyps have a higher potential for malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps; the risk still depends on other factors such as size, morphology, and histological characteristics. The malignancy risk of a solitary flat polyp would need to be assessed based on these factors. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 1356, 1357

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes McBurney's point in cases of acute appendicitis?

options.A: McBurney point is located in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.
options.B: McBurney point corresponds to the site of maximal tenderness in acute appendicitis.
options.C: McBurney point is used to assess rebound tenderness in acute appendicitis.
options.D: McBurney point is located at the umbilicus in acute appendicitis.

questions.explanation: appendicitis. Correct answer B) McBurney point corresponds to the site of maximal tenderness in acute appendicitis Explanation: McBurney point is approximately one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus in the right lower quadrant. It is the site where the appendix is most likely to be inflamed and where maximal tenderness is commonly elicited during physical examination in cases of acute appendicitis. McBurney point is located in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen (Option A) McBurney point is not in the left lower quadrant but rather in the right lower quadrant of the Abdomen. McBurney point is used to assess rebound tenderness in acute appendicitis (Option C) Rebound tenderness is assessed by applying pressure at a different location, typically in the left lower quadrant, and observing if there is increased pain when the pressure is released. McBurney point is located at the umbilicus in acute appendicitis (Option D) McBurney point is not located at the umbilicus but rather in the right lower quadrant. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1339 - 1342

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who has been experiencing fever and pain in the lower right abdomen for the past 5 days, with the presence of a tender mass in the right iliac fossa and an elevated leukocyte count?
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Appendicitis Explanation: Based on the symptoms described, including fever, pain in the right lower abdomen, apainful lump in the right iliac fossa, and an increased leukocyte count, the most probable diagnosis would be appendicitis. Appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix, a small pouch-like organ located in the lower right abdomen. The classic symptoms include fever, abdominal pain (particularly in the right lower quadrant), and an elevated white blood cell count(leukocytosis). The presence of a painful lump in the right iliac fossa further supportsthe likelihood of appendicitis. Hydronephrosis (Option B) Would present with flank pain, not RLQ pain . No fever or leukocytosis unless there is a secondary infection (pyonephrosis) . Ultrasound/CT scan would show dilated renal pelvis and calyces. Tuberculosis (Ileocecal TB) (Option C) TB presents gradually with weight loss, low-grade fever, and chronic pain , not acute severe RLQ pain. A palpable mass may be present (due to a thickened ileocecal region), but no leukocytosis. Carcinoma Colon (Right-Sided) (Option D) Presents insidiously with anemia, weight loss, and altered bowel habits . A firm, non-tender mass may be found in the RLQ butis not typically associated with fever or leukocytosis. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 138, 260, 261

questions.question: What is the diagnosis of a female patient who presents with a mass in the inguinal area that can be reduced from the deep inguinal ring accompanied by a gurgling sound?
questions.explanation: Correct answer B) Indirect inguinal hernia Explanation: Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type, where abdominal contents protrude through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal. They typically manifest as a palpable mass or bulge in the inguinal area, often reducible with manual manipulation, accompanied by a gurgling sound. More prevalent in males, they can be congenital or acquired later in life. Direct inguinal hernia (Option A) Involves protrusion through a weak point in the abdominal wall without passing through the deep inguinal ring. Common in older men, typically lacking the characteristic gurgling sound upon reduction. Femoral hernia (Option C) Arises when abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal, primarily affecting women. Presents as a bulge in the upper thigh or groin area, distinct from the inguinal region, with a narrower passage and typically no gurgling sound upon Reduction. Pantaloon hernia (Option D) A specific type combining direct and indirect hernias, protruding both above and below the inguinal ligament. Presents with bulges on both sides of the inguinal region and may produce a gurgling sound upon reduction. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery (28th edition) page - 1065,1066

questions.question: All of the following are true about Crohn’s disease except
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Rectum is involved Explanation: Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to the anus , but it classically spares the rectum . This is a key differentiating feature from ulcerative colitis , which always involves the rectum . Crohn’s Disease Feature Explanation Transmural involvement Inflammation extends through the entire thickness of the bowel wall Serpiginous ulcers Deep, linear ulcers give a cobblestone appearance to the mucosa Skip lesions Areas of normal mucosa interspersed with diseased segments Recurrence More common than ulcerative colitis, even after surgery Rectal sparing Unlike ulcerative colitis , Crohn’s disease rarely affects the rectum Serpiginous ulcers (Option B): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease typically forms serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers . Transmural involvement (Option C): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease affects all layers of the bowel wall . Recurrence (Option D): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease commonly recurs even after resection. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 855, 883. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1327 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5759609/ Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2474

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true about colon cancer? 1. Right and left colon cancers can behave differently 2. Colon cancers can be hereditary 3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin 4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver
questions.explanation: Right-sided colon cancer (proximal) is more likely to present with anemia, occult bleeding, and larger polypoid tumors , while left-sided colon cancer (distal) presents with obstruction, hematochezia, and napkin-ring lesions . 2. Colon cancers can be hereditary. True Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC/Lynch Syndrome) and Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) are genetic syndromes associated with increased colon cancer risk. 3. Colon cancer risk can be reduced by metformin. True Studies suggest that metformin reduces insulin resistance and suppresses colorectal cancer cell proliferation , lowering the risk, especially in diabetic patients . 4. Colon cancers frequently metastasize to the liver. True The portal venous system drains the colon to the liver , making it the most common site of metastasis. Other common sites include lungs and peritoneum . Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34749618/ Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, pages 1360 - 1364 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10183151/

questions.question: Nonclinical question: Match the following: 1. Hirschsprung’s disease A. MRCP 2. Posterior urethral valve B. CT scan 3. Choledochal cyst C. Rectal biopsy 4. Intussusception D. Micturating cystourethrogram
questions.explanation: Correct answer C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B Explanation: Condition Investigation Explanation Hirschsprung’s disease Rectal biopsy (C) Gold standard test to confirm absence of ganglion cells in the colonic submucosa, leading to functional obstruction. Posterior urethral valve Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) (D) Identifies posterior urethral obstruction due to congenital valves in male infants , causing urinary retention and hydronephrosis. Choledochal cyst MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) (A) Best non-invasive imaging modality to visualize biliary tree anomalies , including cystic dilatation of the common bile duct. Intussusception CT scan (B) (Ultrasound is first-line for children) CT scan shows the "target sign" in adults, while USG is preferred for children , showing characteristic concentric rings. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery (28th Edition) page 989

questions.question: Which of the following structures are incised by a surgeon during an appendectomy performed initially with a gridiron incision? 1. External oblique 2. Internal oblique 3. Transversus abdominis 4. Rectus abdominis
questions.explanation: used for an open appendectomy . The incision is made at McBurney's point (one-third of the way from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus). Layers Incised in a Gridiron Incision: Skin & Subcutaneous tissue External oblique aponeurosis → Incised Internal oblique muscle → Split along its fibers (NOT cut transversely) Transversus abdominis muscle → Split along its fibers Transversalis fascia & Peritoneum → Opened to access the appendix Why Not Rectus Abdominis? Rectus abdominis is NOT involved because the gridiron incision is made in the right lower quadrant , where the rectus abdominis does not extend laterally. If a paramedian or midline incision were used, rectus abdominis would be involved Reference: Pubmed SRB's Manual of Surgery (6th Edition), Page 934, 1156.

questions.question: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?

options.D: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Foreign body in the esophagus Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is foreign body in the esophagus , as suggested by the X-ray showing an object lodged in the esophagus, causing difficulty swallowing. Category Indications Management Emergency Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions) Disk batteries Sharp-pointed objects Immediate endoscopic removal Urgent Blunt objects Incomplete obstruction Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach) Coins Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours Non Urgent Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks Observation Foreign body in the trachea (Option A) would cause symptoms like coughing, wheezing, or stridor, but it typically appears as an object in the trachea on X-ray, which is not the case here. Artifacts (Option C) are typically caused by external factors like motion or poor technique during the X-ray, which would not show a clear foreign body in the esophagus. Soft tissue calcification in the neck (Option D) refers to calcified structures in the neck, such as lymph nodes or blood vessels, but would not present as a foreign object causing swallowing difficulty. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 262. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1036.

questions.question: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach, which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy Explanation: The most appropriate management for a patient with a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach involving the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver is Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy. Treatment of Stomach Cancer Surgical Treatment: Surgical resection is the only curative treatment for gastric cancer. Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Most surgical candidates receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy to improve survival. The FLOT4 trial found that the FLOT (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) regimen offers a significant survival advantage over the ECF (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-fluorouracil) regimen (median overall survival: 50 months vs 35 months). Types of Gastric Resection Total Gastrectomy: Involves the removal of the stomach, spleen, and pancreas. Includes D2 lymphadenectomy. Preferred for resectable gastric cancer. Subtotal Gastrectomy: It may be performed if the tumour is located in the distal stomach. Involves Roux-en-Y reconstruction. Palliative Surgery: Considered for symptom alleviation in inoperable or metastatic gastric cancer. Non-Surgical Treatment Palliative Chemotherapy or Radiotherapy: Offered to patients with advanced gastric cancer. Radical gastrectomy (Option B) would be considered if there was no metastasis, but metastasis to the liver and involvement of the pancreas suggests an advanced stage, making this option less feasible. Whipple's procedure (Option C) is used for pancreatic cancer; this procedure is not appropriate here due to gastric cancer with liver metastasis. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy (Option D) would be considered for resectable localised tumours, but with liver metastasis, it’s not an ideal option for curative intent. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pg 1174, 1175, 1177

questions.question: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

options.B: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
options.D: Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair Explanation: The medial bulge near the inferior epigastric vessels suggests a direct Inguinal Hernia , which protrudes through a weakness in Hesselbach's triangle and is treated with Lichtenstein mesh repair. It is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia). (Option C, and D ruled out) Management of Inguinal Hernia: Surgical Approaches: Herniotomy : It involves excising and closing the hernia sac Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele. In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates. Hernioplasty : Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh. Herniorrhaphy : Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures Techniques: Bassini's Repair: Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair. Higher recurrence rates. (Option A ruled out) Shouldice Repair: involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's. Modified Shouldice : A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement. Anterior Tension-Free Repair: Lichtenstein Repair (preferred): Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. (Option A ruled out) Open Preperitoneal Repair: Stoppa Repair : Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia Laparoscopic Hernia Repair: Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair TEP TAPP Procedure Surgery done above the peritoneum Surgery done beneath the peritoneum Advantages Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications. Reduced risk of adhesions. Larger working space Better visualisation Disadvantages Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging. A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity. Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP.

questions.question: A patient with rectal prolapse underwent surgery. The postoperative image is given below. Identify the Procedure.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Thiersch wiring Explanation: The procedure shown is Thiersch wiring , a technique for managing Rectal Prolapse by applying wires or sutures to support the rectal mucosa. It is the circumferential descent of the rectum through the anal canal Management of Rectal Prolapse: Non-Operative Management Medical Treatment: Palliates symptoms of constipation and faecal incontinence with fluid intake, fibre supplements, stool softeners, and topical treatments for mucosal oedema. Enemas and Suppositories: Assist in defecation and reduce symptoms. Operative Management Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilization of the rectum. Aspect Abdominal Rectopexy Perineal Rectopexy Types Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein Suture rectopexy- Lahaut Anterior Resection Resection Rectopexy Mucosal sleeve resection ( Delrome's ) Perineal recto sigmoidectomy ( Altemeier's ) Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is correct? 1. Autosomal dominant disease 2. Defect in the STK11 gene 3. Melanin spots on digits and perianal skin 4. Autosomal recessive 5. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is seen
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome : It is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by a loss of function mutation in the STK11 gene (statements 1 & 2) (statement 4 ruled out) It presents around 11 years of age. Most cases are asymptomatic but may present with chronic bleeding, anaemia, or intussusception. Histology: An arborising pattern of smooth muscle and glands lined by normal epithelium. It is characterised by: Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, perianal region and extremities) (statement 3) Polyps are large, pedunculated, and lobulated. Significant risk of cancers: Small bowel, colon, pancreas, lungs, testis, ovaries, breast, and endometrium Lifetime cancer risk is estimated at 40%

questions.question: A 40-year-old man presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain. On examination, his HR is 110 bpm, BP-88/60 mmHg. Guarding is present on per abdomen examination. Erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would you proceed with for the management of this case? A. USG abdomen B. IV fluids C. Exploratory laparotomy D. Elective surgery E. Conservative management
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) B & C Explanation: The patient’s presentation, along with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) visible on the erect abdominal X-ray, strongly suggests the perforation of a hollow organ. The most appropriate management for this patient, who likely has a gastrointestinal perforation , is to administer IV fluids to stabilise the patient and then proceed with exploratory laparotomy for immediate surgical intervention. Elective surgery is not appropriate for a patient with an acute perforation as it is an emergency, and delaying surgery for an elective procedure would be harmful. (Statement D ruled out) Imaging is already done (X-ray showing free air), so no further imaging (like ultrasound) is required immediately, and conservative management would not be effective or appropriate in this emergency situation. (Statement A & E ruled out) Pneumoperitoneum Causes: Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy. Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum. Diagnosis on Imaging: Erect CXR:

(Option B ruled out) Inguinal Hernia is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia). questions.question: A man in his middle age arrives with a gradual onset of challenges while swallowing both solid and liquid substances over the course of 8 months. The results of a barium swallow test conducted are provided below. What additional examinations should be conducted for this individual?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry Explanation : Given that the barium swallow findings are suggestive of achalasia , the appropriate next steps are to perform an upper GI endoscopy to rule out any other structural causes and oesophagal manometry to confirm the diagnosis. Achalasia cardia Definition It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing Clinical Features Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids. Regurgitation Halitosis Chest Pain Weight Loss Investigations: Esophageal Manometry Gold Standard : This is the definitive diagnostic test for

questions.question: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following can be seen in this child? A. Bilious vomiting B. Visible peristalsis from left to right C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia D. Metabolic alkalosis
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) B, C and D Explanation: Visible peristalsis from left to right, hypochloremia and hypokalemia, and Metabolic alkalosis are seen in a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) Definition It is a condition involving hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in male infants, typically between 2 - 6 weeks of age. Clinical Presentation Symptoms: Projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeds, starting around 2 to 6 weeks of age. (Statement A ruled out) Persistent vomiting leads to dehydration, hypokalemia and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis because the body loses hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the vomitus. Physical Examination: Visible gastric peristalsis from left to right and a palpable “olive-shaped” mass in the epigastric region. Diagnosis Ultrasound (USG) is the Investigation of choice for CHPS, characterised by Pyloric muscle thickness of > 3 mm Pyloric length > 14 mm The pyloric channel appears elongated and thickened (10-14 mm) Contrast Studies (Upper GI Series): Less frequently used, demonstrating the classic "string sign" with a thin line of contrast through the elongated and narrowed pyloric channel and delayed gastric emptying without duodenal dilation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Tillaux sign?

options.A: Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
options.C: Mass is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line Explanation: Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery accurately describes the Tillaux sign which is a component of Tillaux’s triad. Tillaux’s triad is associated with mesenteric cysts. Mesenteric cysts Definition It presents as a painless abdominal swelling in the umbilical region. Commonly seen in the 2nd decade of life. There is a band of resonance in front of the cyst. Tillaux's triad for mesenteric cysts A soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region. (Option A ruled out) Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery (Tillaux Sign) A zone of resonance all around. Complications Torsion of cysts can lead to volvulus of the adjacent bowel. Rupture of the cyst. Hemorrhage into the cyst. Infection Mass is brilliantly transilluminate (Option B): Transillumination refers to shining light through a cyst or mass and observing whether the light passes through, indicating it is filled with fluid or air. However, Tillaux’s sign is about the movement of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery . Fluctuation is positive (Option D): Fluctuation is a clinical sign used to detect fluid-filled masses noted in cases like hydatid cysts or cystic lesions. However, fluctuation is not specific to the Tillaux sign , which does not focus on detecting fluid content within the mass. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 569, 570

questions.question: Which of the options accurately represents a valid statement concerning retroperitoneal trauma?

options.A: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
options.B: Zone 3 injury, whether blunt or penetrative, should always be explored
options.C: Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
options.D: Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the Aorta

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically Zone 2, expanding hematoma confined to the lateral retroperitoneum without active bleeding and hemodynamically stable patient angioembolisation is a suitable option to prevent or control bleeding while avoiding the risks associated with open surgery. Angioembolization is a minimally invasive procedure that involves the selective occlusion of bleeding vessels. The retroperitoneum is divided into three zones for intraoperative management in blunt trauma: Zone I – Central Associated with injuries of The aorta & its proximal branches Inferior vena cava & its proximal tributaries Management: Central hematoma - exploration with proximal & distal vascular control (Option A ruled out) . Zone 2 - Lateral Structures located - Distal renal vessels Management: Lateral hematoma (renal in origin) - managed nonoperatively (angioembolisation) (Option C) Pulsatile hematoma or penetrating injury present - exploration. Zone 3 - Pelvic Confined to the retroperitoneal zone of the pelvis Structures located - Iliac vessels Management: Pelvic hematoma is exceptionally difficult to control. Usually, it should not be opened. It is managed by packing/angioembolisation. Explored only if there is expanding or pulsatile, or penetrating injury present. (Option B ruled out) Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilised to the right to visualise the Aorta (Option D). This is incorrect because the Mattox maneuver, also known as a left medial visceral rotation, is a surgical step to explore and handle Zone 1 and 2 retroperitoneal injuries, it involves mobilising the left colon (not the ascending colon) to gain better access to the aorta and other retroperitoneal structures for surgery.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lightweight mesh with large pores Explanation: The mesh that is most appropriate for use during hernioplasty is Lightweight mesh with large pores. The choice of mesh is important as it affects the outcome of the procedure and the long-term success of the hernia repair. Lightweight: It provides sufficient strength and support while minimising the risk of complications like mesh-related pain and discomfort. The reduced material leads to less inflammation and tissue reaction, which improves patient comfort and recovery. (Options A & B ruled out) Large pores: Large-pore meshes allow better tissue integration, enabling the mesh to become well-incorporated into the patient’s tissue. This improves healing and reduces complications like infection or seroma formation. The flexibility of large-pore meshes also helps with the natural movement of the abdominal wall, which is essential for long-term functionality. (Options A & C ruled out) Reference: NIH Link

questions.question: According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 incisional hernia refers to:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Umbilical Explanation: According to the European Hernia Society (EHS) classification , M3 refers to an incisional hernia located in the umbilical region. The classification divides incisional hernias into two main categories: Midline & Lateral. EHS Classification of Incisional Hernia Midline Subxiphoid M1 Epigastric (Option A ruledout) M2 Umbilical M3 Infraumbilical (Option B ruledout) M4 Suprapubic (Option D ruledout) M5 Lateral Subcostal L1 Flank L2 Iliac L3 Lumbar L4 Reference: Researchgate Link .

questions.question: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the Chicago classification, which type of achalasia does the patient have?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Type III The given description in the question, massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions , corresponds to Type III achalasia and is defined by spastic contractions of the oesophagus. Chicago Classification of Esophageal Motility (4.0) Esophageal Disorder Description Values 1. Achalasia Type I Minimal contractility (Option B ruled out) IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis Type II Esophageal pan-pressurization (Option A ruled out) IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, 100% failed peristalsis with ≥ 20% pan-esophageal pressurisation Type III Spastic contractions (Option D) IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, ≥ 20% spastic contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm) 2. Esophagogastric Junction Outflow Obstruction (EGJOO) Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (IRP) with preserved peristalsis IRP ≥ 15 mmHg, some preserved peristalsis 3. Distal Esophageal Spasm (DES) Premature (rapid) contractions with normal IRP Normal IRP, ≥ 20% premature contractions (DL < 4.5 s) 4. Hypercontractile (Jackhammer) Esophagus Extremely strong peristaltic contractions Normal IRP, ≥ 20% hypercontractile contractions (DCI > 8,000 mmHg·s·cm) 5. Ineffective Esophageal Motility (IEM) Weak or failed peristalsis Normal IRP, > 50% ineffective swallows (DCI < 450 mmHg·s·cm for weak peristalsis) 6. Absent Contractility Complete lack of esophageal contractility Normal IRP, 100% failed peristalsis Type IV (Option C) is not part of the classification mentioned above. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1122

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a middle-aged man who comes to the emergency department with upper abdominal pain following a large meal? During clinical examination, there is tenderness in the upper abdomen, and a chest X-ray reveals a widening of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum.

options.D: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of the lung

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Spontaneous perforation of esophagus The given presentation, along with the findings on chest X-ray, is suggestive of esophageal perforation , particularly a spontaneous perforation (also known as Boerhaave syndrome ). It is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure, typically from vomiting against a closed glottis resulting in a left-sided esophageal perforation . The rupture leads the gastric contents to spill into the pleural cavity, leading to a left pleural effusion and subcutaneous emphysema . Classic triad : Mackler’s triad (Vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema). Symptoms : May include fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea in the presence of sepsis. Physical exam : Hamman’s sign (crunching sound on auscultation due to surgical emphysema). Complications : Pneumothorax, mediastinitis, and sepsis. Perforation of peptic ulcer (Option B) can cause localised abdominal pain and even air under the diaphragm, but not pneumomediastinum . Foreign body in esophagus (Option C) presents with dysphagia, odynophagia, and discomfort . The clinical signs and pneumomediastinum on the X-ray are more suggestive of perforation or rupture rather than foreign body ingestion. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of the lung (Option D) generally presents with respiratory symptoms like chest pain, shortness of breath, or cough , particularly in patients with COPD. The lack of these symptoms makes it less likely than oesophagal perforation. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1127, 1128 NIH Link

questions.question: What is the most frequently encountered neuroendocrine tumour in the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Insulinoma Insulinoma is the most common type of neuroendocrine tumour found in the pancreas, which is usually benign and results in excessive insulin secretion , causing hypoglycemia. Insulinoma Category Details Definition A rare, typically benign tumour of the pancreatic islet cells that produce excess insulin. Clinical Features Whipple's Triad: Documented low blood glucose levels during symptomatic episodes Relief of symptoms upon administration of glucose Symptoms often occur during fasting or after exercise Symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., sweating, palpitations, confusion, visual disturbances, seizures) Diagnosis Gold-standard test for diagnosing insulinoma is a 72-hour fast. Combination of plasma glucose < 55 mg/dL + insulin level ≥ 3 microUnits/mL + C peptide level ≥ to 0.6 ng/mL + proinsulin ≥ 5 pmol/L, + negative sulfonylurea level indicates that the hypoglycemia induction is by hyperinsulinemia Insulin/glucose ratio > 0.4 is diagnostic Imaging: CT, MRI, EUS Management Surgical resection is the treatment of choice. Medical management with diazoxide or octreotide for non-surgical candidates or unresectable tumours. Gastrinoma (Option A) is a neuroendocrine tumour that arises from the cells producing gastrin in the pancreas. While they are commonly associated with a condition called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which involves excessive gastrin production and gastric acid hypersecretion, they are less common than insulinomas. Somatostatinoma (Option B) is a somatostatin- secreting tumour usually found in the pancreas or duodenum and is rarely associated with MEN1 syndrome . VIPoma (Option D) is a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours that produce vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). They cause Verner-Morrison syndrome , characterised by watery diarrhoea , hypokalemia , and achlorhydria . VIPomas are much less common than insulinomas. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 906, 907. Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 665.

questions.question: What stage of Hinchey's classification is indicated when a patient with clinical features suggestive of peritonitis presents with diverticular perforation and faecal peritonitis during surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Stage 4 The presence of faecal peritonitis indicates that faecal material has spilled into the peritoneal cavity, which is a hallmark of Stage 4 in the Hinchey classification. The Hinchey classification is used to stage the severity of diverticulitis and its associated complications . Modified Hinchey Classification (Severity of acute diverticulitis) Stage 0 Mild diverticulitis Stage 1 (Option A ruled out) Ia : Pericolic inflammation Ib : Pericolic abscess Stage 2 (Option B ruled out) Pelvic or intra-abdominal abscess Stage 3 (Option C ruled out) Purulent peritonitis Stage 4 Fecal peritonitis Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1368-1370 SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Pages 879-882

questions.question: In MEN 1 syndrome, where is the most frequent occurrence of gastrinoma observed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Duodenum In MEN 1 syndrome, the most frequent occurrence of gastrinomas is in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are tumours that secrete gastrin , a hormone that stimulates acid production in the stomach. This leads to conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome . These tumours are mainly found in the small intestine or pancreas , with the duodenum being the most common extrapancreatic site for gastrinomas. (Other options ruled out) While surgical resection is indicated in some cases, it is not curative in all. Surgical resection can be curative only if metastasis is absent. Treatment involves proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid suppression, high-dose PPI therapy for acid control, and somatostatin analogues as adjunctive therapy Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 773. Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Pages 2983 - 2990.

questions.question: A middle-aged man presents with a gradual onset of swallowing difficulties for both solid and liquid foods, persisting for 8 months. The barium swallow test results are presented below. The patient undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and manometry. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this condition?

options.A: Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux
options.B: <75% relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter
options.C: It is a primary motility disorder

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Loss of lower esophageal sphincter pressure causing reflux Explanation: The given condition, along with the barium swallow finding, is suggestive of Achalasia cardia, which is characterised by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax. Achalasia is associated with increased pressure rather than a loss of pressure of the LES. Achalasia cardia Definition It is a primary motility disorder (Option B ruled out) characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall, which leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower oesophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing (Option A & D ruled out) Clinical Features Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.

questions.question: What would be the subsequent course of action for managing a 35-year-old woman who has been experiencing swelling in her right groin for the past six months, as determined during her arrival at the emergency department? Upon examination, a reducible hernia is observed in the right groin without any signs of strangulation.

options.B: Reduce the swelling and later observe
options.C: Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery Explanation: For a reducible hernia with no signs of strangulation , the correct course of action is to reduce the swelling and proceed with elective surgery . A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall. They are at a higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias. Hence, elective surgery is advised to repair the hernia and prevent complications. Exploratory laparotomy (Option A) is an invasive procedure that is usually performed when there is concern about internal injury, peritonitis, or significant abdominal pathology. In this case, since the hernia is reducible and there are no signs of strangulation, a laparotomy is not needed. Reduce the swelling and later observe (Option B) is not ideal as a surgical intervention should still be planned in the near future to prevent any complications like recurrent or incarcerated hernias. A CT abdomen (Option D) is not necessary here because the diagnosis of a reducible hernia is already done, and there are no signs of strangulation. It may be required if there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or if other abdominal pathologies are suspected. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1062, 1063

questions.question: The likely diagnosis for a newborn infant presenting with signs of intestinal obstruction, as indicated by the x-ray image and CT abdomen showing an annular pancreas, is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Duodenal atresia Explanation: The given x-ray shows a classic finding of Duodenal atresia, which is the "double bubble" sign , where there are two air-filled spaces visible: one in the stomach and one in the duodenum, indicating obstruction at the level of the duodenum . Duodenal Atresia Pathophysiology Failed recanalisation of intestinal lumen during gestation Associated Conditions Prematurity (50%) Congenital anomalies (heart disease, malrotation, annular pancreas, etc.) Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 21) Clinical Presentation Bilious vomiting without abdominal distention. Symptoms typically present within the first few days of life. Diagnosis Confirmed by the double bubble sign on the abdominal X-ray and prenatal ultrasonography. Treatment Initial: Nasogastric decompression and IV fluids Definitive: Surgical repair (Duodenoduodenostomy) Postoperative care: Gastrostomy tube, nutritional support Jejunoileal atresia (Option A)

questions.question: A patient who underwent Nissen’s fundoplication was seen in the ward during evening rounds. He is asymptomatic at present and has stable vitals. What is the next line of management for this patient?

options.A: Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome
options.B: Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Monitor vitals Explanation: Given that the patient is asymptomatic and has stable vitals , the primary management at this stage is to continue monitoring their vitals closely. Nissen fundoplication is a surgical procedure used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD); it involves wrapping the upper part of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to increase the pressure at the lower oesophagal sphincter (LES), reducing reflux. Management of GERD Lifestyle Changes Elevate the head of the bed Avoid lying down after meals Quit smoking Medical management Antacids: Neutralize stomach acid H2-receptor antagonists: Ranitidine, Famotidine Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): Omeprazole, Esomeprazole Surgical management Antireflux operation: 3 components Restoration of the intra-abdominal segment of the esophagus Crural repair Reinforcement of the LES by the upper stomach or prosthesis. Fundoplication: A surgical procedure to wrap the top of the stomach around the lower oesophagus to strengthen the sphincter. Complete fundoplication (Nissen) Partial fundoplication: Posteriorly (Toupet) or Anteriorly(Dor, Watson) has few short-term side effects but has a higher long-term failure rate. Transoral Incisionless Fundoplication (TIF): An endoscopic procedure performed through the mouth but may be less effective for severe GERD and not suitable for all patients. Magnetic Sphincter Augmentation (LINX Device): Involves implanting a ring of magnetic beads around the lower oesophagal sphincter to enhance its function and prevent reflux. Nasogastric tube to prevent gas bloat syndrome (Option A): While gas bloat syndrome can be a complication post-surgery, it would not necessitate routine nasogastric tube insertion unless symptoms of bloating or distension arise. Insert chest tube to prevent pneumothorax (Option B): There is no indication of a pneumothorax, and the patient is asymptomatic with stable vitals, making a chest tube unnecessary. Imaging to rule out perforation (Option D) is not recommended as the patient is asymptomatic and stable, without signs of perforation. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 1115, 1116, 1117

questions.question: Which of the following do not require instruments to examine?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Acute anal fissure Explanation: An acute anal fissure is a fresh, superficial tear in the anal canal lining typically caused by trauma, such as passing a large stool. It can be diagnosed through a visual inspection and digital rectal examination without the need for any specialised instruments like anoscopes or proctoscopes. Carcinoma rectum (Option B) requires a sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy to visualise and assess the tumour's extent. Imaging studies are also needed to evaluate staging. Haemorrhoids (Option C): While external haemorrhoids can be diagnosed through visual inspection , internal haemorrhoids typically require the use of an anoscope or proctoscope for proper assessment. Rectal polyps (Option D) are usually diagnosed and removed using colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy , making instruments necessary for both diagnosis and treatment. Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, page 1395
